Graphical abstract In recent years bi-metallic materials have shown promising effect as potential catalyst layer in the fuel cells. Here, for the first time, bimetallic Ag-Pd were electrodeposited on polyaniline/glassy carbon electrode (PANI/GCE) via the constant current method, which used as efficient electrode for ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR) in alkaline media. Some important parameters including applied current, deposition time and metal ratio were optimized. The obtained bimetallic AgPd/PANI/GCE catalyst showed improved catalytic performance for ethanol conversion compared with the Pd/PANI/GCE, Pd/GCE, Ag/PANI/GCE, and PANI/GCE. The catalytic enhancement is due to the synergic effect between Ag, Pd and PANI. Moreover, the proposed AgPd composite was deposited on the carbon fiber cloth (CC) to evaluate its applicability as an anode in ethanol fuel cell. To summarize, the good electrochemical performance and easy preparation make the obtained Ag-Pd bimetallic composite as a potential candidate for alkaline ethanol fuel cell. Keywords Polyaniline Ethanol oxidation Palladium-silver bi-metallic Fuel cell Carbon fiber cloth Glassy carbon electrode 1 Introduction Nowadays along with the increasing demand for clean and renewable energy, it is urgent need for the investigation of alternative fuels. Fuel cell as one of the most promising novel technology has been extensively studied. However, the performance of fuel cell is the key challenge. Several efforts have been paid to enhance the fuel cell performance, for instance, by investigating new economic and efficient catalysts [1]. Carbon supported platinum is usually used as anode or cathode electrocatalyst in low-temperature hydrogen or low molecular weight alcohols fuel cells. Although with good performance, the high cost and scarce resources of noble metal materials has limited it spread applications [2]. In addition, platinum used as anode material is tend to be poisoned by the carbon monoxide (CO) that present in contaminant from H2 fuel cells or as byproduct from alcohol oxidation in direct alcohol fuel cells [2]. To address this issue, palladium is recognized as anti-poisoning of CO, however, suffering inactivation problem in alkaline media and high cost [3–5]. Therefore a number of attempts have been done to reduce the usage of these precious metals in the catalyst layers in cathode and anode [6,7]. To reduce the loading amount and enhance the catalytic effect of Pd or Pt, researchers put efforts on the investigation of bimetlllic and/or trimetallic composition. For example, bi-metallic Pt–Sn, Pt–Ir and tri-metallic Pt–Ir–Sn catalysts was developed for electro-oxidation of ethanol in the direct ethanol fuel cell [8]. In another study, bimetallic Pd-Au catalyst has been synthesized for ethanol electro-oxidation in an alkaline medium. The result showed that the addition of 50–90 at.% of Au to Pd led to significant enhancement for the active ethanol electro-oxidation [9]. Conductive polymers (CPs) are attractive in both of fundamental and practical studies because of their electrical and electrochemical properties, which make them as traditional semiconductors and metals [10]. CPs have several advantages such as moderate synthesis, processing conditions, tunable conductivity, chemical and structural variety and structural flexibility [10]. These polymers and their composites with metals have various applications especially in electrochemical fields such as sensors [11], batteries [12], supercapacitors [13] and fuel cells [14,15]. One of the common CPs is polyaniline (PANI) which has been widely used for many electrochemical applications either as a conducting agent or directly as an electroactive material. In some biosensors, the presence of PANI improves the selectivity and stability of the sensor [16]. It is found from several studies that the presence of PANI reduced poisoning of the electrode in alcohol fuel cell. Pd loaded on PANI materials are intensively utilized as versatile materials for several application [17,18], especially used in fuel cells [19]. Deposition of Pd on PANI has been done by chemical [19,20] and electrochemical methods [21,22]. The synergistic effect between Pd with PANI has promoted the catalytic activity in fuel cells [21,23]. Kakaei et al. has developed a Ag-Pd alloy on reduced graphene oxide for ethanol oxidation in alkaline media [24]. Although Ag has no catalytic effect for EOR, it has exhibited promotive effect when alloy with Pd. There are some other reports which have used AgPd bi-metallic catalyst for non-enzymatic glucose biosensor [25], formic acid oxidation [26], glycerol oxidation [27], borohydride fuel cells and oxygen reduction reaction [28]. According to volcano plot, there are some elements, although have no considerable catalyzing effect, showed excellent improved catalytic effect on Pt and Pd catalysts. To the best of our knowledge, there is no report about using bimetallic Pd and Ag on PANI substrate as electrode for electroncatalysis application. For the first time we synthesize bi-metallic Pd and Ag deposited on PANI and this composite was used as the catalyst layer for EOR. The results showed that this bimetallic compound in the presence of PANI is more effective than that without PANI, and exhibited much better catalytic performance than monometallic Pd and Ag deposited on PANI. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and solutions Aniline (ANI) monomer, silver nitrate, sulfuric acid (98%), potassium nitrate, ammonia solution (25%), nitric acid (65%) and sodium hydroxide all in analytical grade were purchased from Merck company. Palladium chloride (PdCl2, 60% Pd) was obtained from Fluka company. All reagents were used without any purification, except aniline which was distilled before use. The aqueous solutions were prepared with deionized (DI) water. 2.2 Apparatus and software Electrochemical measurements were done with Potentiostat/Galvanostat model of μ-Autolab Tape II. Electrochemical impedance measurements were accomplished with Potentiostat/Galvanostat equipped with FRA (Autolab PGSTAT 30). The software for analyzing electrochemical data was Nova 1.11.1. Electrochemical cell consists of three electrodes (modified and bare GCE or CC, Pt rod and Ag/AgCl (3 M KCl) as working, counter and reference electrodes, respectively. The glassy carbon disk electrode had a diameter of 3 mm and the CC weight was 200 g m−2 (ISO 3374) with the thickness of 0.25 mm. The properties of the composite were investigated by different techniques. Morphology and elemental analysis of the electrode surfaces were studied by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (TESCAN/VEGA2, Czech Republic) equipped with energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern was obtained by scan step of 0.06° s−1 with a Philips-pw 1800 diffractometer, which was equipped with Cu-Kα irradiation (λ = 0.1524 nm) source. To investigate the Pd and Ag loading on the electrode surface, inductively coupled plasma (ICP) instrument (Shimadzu, ICPS-7000, Japan) was used. 2.3 GCE modification For electrode modification, GCE surface was polished with alumina powder (0.05 μm) on a polishing pad, and then rinsed with DI water. After this PANI layer was deposited on the electrode surface in the solution containing 0.03 M ANI and 0.5 M H2SO4 by applying 10 successive cyclic voltammograms (CVs) with the scan rate of 0.05 V s−1 in the potential range of −0.2 to 1.0 V. This electrode is named PANI/GCE. Pd and Ag were deposited simultaneously on the PANI/GCE in an ammonia buffer solution (0.5 M, pH = 9.2) containing 0.1 M KNO3, 1 mM AgNO3 and 1 mM PdCl2 by applying various cathodic constant current with different times. Then the electrodes were washed with DI water and dried with Ar gas. These electrodes are named as AgPd/PANI/GCE. To investigate the EOR performance, the electrodes were immersed in 0.5 M NaOH containing 1 M EtOH and 5 successive CVs from −1 to 0.6 V was applied. For comparing, with the same procedure and at the optimum conditions for AgPd/PANI/GCE, Pd and Ag were deposited separately on PANI/GCE, these electrodes are named as Pd/PANI/GCE and Ag/PANI/GCE respectively. For investigation of PANI layer effect, GCEs modified with Ag, Pd and AgPd in the absent of PANI layer were prepared at the same electrochemical conditions, which are named as Ag/GCE, Pd/GCE and AgPd/GCE, respectively. 2.4 Modification of CC Since CC was widely used as current collector in fuel cells, CC was applied as substrate for the bimetallic Ag-Pd composite to create applicable electrode. To prepare CC electrode, a piece of CC was glued on a Teflon sheet and the electrical connection was established with a copper wire. All required insulations were done with an epoxy glue. Before electrodepositions on CC, its surface was degreased with acetone and then washed with DI water. The same modifications were done for CC with a miner change in PANI deposition step, i.e. the potential range for applying 10 successive CVs was between −0.4 to 1.2 V, but the other conditions were same with previous process for GCE. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Electrode characterization by SEM To investigate the surface morphology, the prepared electrodes were imaged by SEM. Different magnification images of the PANI/GCE and AgPd/PANI/GCE were demonstrated in Fig. 1 . From Fig. 1A, it shows that the PANI is deposited as wire and particle morphology, indicating an improvement of the contact surface area. The shape and morphology of PANI is dependent on synthesis conditions and various morphologies have been reported. For example zero-dimensional (nanospheres), one-dimensional (nanowire, nanorod, nanoneedle, rice-like nanostructure, nanotube), two-dimensional (nanoribbon, nanosheet, nanoring, net-like nanostructure), and three-dimensional (hollow nanosphere, polyhedral nanoparticle, flower-like, rhizoid-like, brain-like, urchin-like, and star-like) nanostructures [29]. In this study the electrochemical conditions for PANI electropolymerization is close to a previous work [30] and the PANI morphology is almost similar to this report. Fig. 1B–D show that Ag and Pd are deposited with dendrite shapes. The main skeleton for Ag serve as subtract to deposit the Pd particles. To ensure the presence of Pd nanoparticles on the surface of this structure, elemental mapping was investigated. Fig. 2 A illustrates that the Pd particles (purple dots) are distributed uniformly on the surface. As a result, these dendrite structures provide a larger Pd surface area as active site which increases the catalytic activity toward EOR when exposed to ethanol. To characterize the bimetallic morphology on CC surface, SEM images were taken. Fig. 3 (A and B) shows PANI deposited on CC with two morphologies (film and massive on the film). The massive structure mostly deposited close to the edges of the CC sheet, which may be due to the more current density on the edges, while the main structure is as a film layer. It is possible if we use Pt foil instead of rod as counter electrode, the current density on CC electrode would more uniform and consequently the PANI morphology would more uniform. Fig. 3(C–G) shows that AgPd bimetallic and dendritic structure is formed on AgPd/PANI/CC, in coincidence with the formation way on AgPd/PANI/GCE. Similarity, the Pd particles are homogeneously distributed on the Ag skeleton (Fig. 4 ). Beside the discussed benefits, dendritic bimetallic catalysts in nanoscale provide a larger surface area as a great advantage compared to spherical nanocatalysts, which subsequently lead to much enhanced activity. Additional advantage of bimetallic catalysts is their low cost [31]. This is achieved when a more expensive metal (in this case Pd) is positioned on the surface of relatively low-cost metal (in this case Ag) and consequently can be directly accessed to the fuel (ethanol). As shown in Fig. 5 A and B, Ag/PANI/CC exhibits a dendritic structure which confirms the main and dendritic structure is related to Ag in AgPd/PANI/CC, while the Pd on PANI/CC presents in particle shape. Fig. 6 B illustrates the EDS spectrum for Pd/PANI/CC which verifies the successfully deposition of Pd on PANI/CC. The mapping analysis as shown in Fig. 6A indicated the uniform deposition of Pd on PANI. Finally, the morphologies of AgPd/CC and Pd/CC were also investigated by SEM (Figs. 7A and 8 ). Fig. 7C shows that Pd is deposited as nanoparticles and AgPd dendritic structure is not obvious, which is similar with previously observation in AgPd/PANI/CC. The last observation indicates the rule of PANI substrate for creation of the dendritic structure of AgPd. 3.2 XRD investigation In this study four electrodes (PANI/CC, Ag/PANI/CC, Pd/PANI/CC and AgPd/PANI/CC) were prepared at optimum conditions and the chemical structure on the electrodes surface was investigated by XRD. Fig. 9 shows the XRD patterns of unmodified and modified CC electrodes. According to 00.001.0640 reference code, in the bare carbon cloth pattern the peaks around 26, 43 and 54° are related to (0 0 2), (1 0 0) and (0 0 4) planes of hexagonal carbon, respectively and these peaks are observed in all other XRD patterns. The amorphous structure of PANI has no obvious peak in PANI/CC. In the Ag/PANI/CC pattern, the peak at 38.3° is related to (1 1 1) plane of Ag which is according to 00.002.1098 reference code of cubic silver. The peak at 40° in Pd/PANI/CC pattern is related to (1 1 1) plane of Pd with the cubic crystal structure (Reference code: 00-046-1043). The diffraction peaks of AgPd/PANI/CC show that the finger prints corresponding to Ag and Pd are both appear in a new 2θ position between the Ag and Pd peaks, which evident the formation of AgPd alloy. 3.3 ICP analysis To evaluate the amount of Pd and Ag loaded on GCE and CC, ICP technique was conducted. After the deposition process on the electrode surfaces at optimum conditions, the deposited layer was dissolved in 3 mL of HNO3 4 M at 50 °C overnight. The resulted solution was then diluted into 5 mL in a volumetric flask. Standard solutions of Pd and Ag were prepared in HNO3 and their corresponding calibration curves were plotted via ICP technique. Calculated by the standard curve plots, the amount of each element on the electrodes surface was measured. The results have been summarized in Table 1 . 3.4 Optimization of some electrochemical parameters for composite deposition 3.4.1 Deposition current Fig. 10 shows 10 successive CVs of PANI electrodeposition on GCE. The redox peaks related to ANI polymerization are obviously observed. First cycle shows the first oxidation of aniline at 0.9 V approximately [32]. From the second cycle, the anodic and cathodic currents continuously increased, suggesting the consistent growth of PANI [33]. Unlike other known electroconductive polymers, polyaniline can exist, depending on the degree of oxidation, in different forms. It is known as leuoemeraldine (LE), emeraldine (EM) and perningraniline (PE). LE refers to fully reduced form of PANI, EM is half-oxidized, and PE is a completely oxidized form of it. The only conducting form of polyaniline is EM salt, which obtained by doping or protonation of EM base [34]. A general mechanism of electrochemical polymerization could not be established because of various factors that influence the polymerization process. However, it is believed that electrochemical polymerization consists of three different steps. In first step oxidation of the monomer at anode lead to the formation of soluble oligomers in the diffusion layer. Secondly deposition of oligomers occurs through nucleation and growth process. In the third step chain propagation was processed by solid state polymerization [34]. The first redox peak at about 0.2 V corresponds to the transition of the LE to EM at the forward scan, and switching back to LE can be seen at the backward scan. It was verified that the second pair of peaks (0.5 V) may have a different origin: it can related to the presence of oligomers or degradation products, the presence of orto-coupled polymer segments cause to build the polymer matrix or the formation of cross-linked chains [35]. The third redox peak at about 0.8 V corresponds to the transition of EM to PE, while on the reversed scan, the PE reduction to EM is observed. Additionally, in the subsequent cycles, the potential of ANI oxidation shifts to lower values and overlaps with the range of the second redox pair. Then AgPd was deposited in 10 min on PANI/GCE with different constant currents (−0.1, −0.5, −1 and −2 mA) and their EOR performance were investigated in alkaline media. The forward peak current (i f), backward peak current (i b), i f/i b ratio, the EOR onset (E op) and peak potential (E p) at each applied constant current were summarized in Table 2 . The results show that although Ep is more positive at −2.0 mA, E op is more negative. It means that EOR starts in more thermodynamically easier conditions. The greater i f/i b suggests the lower chance to be poisoned of the catalyst with oxidation products. At this current the if value is much greater than the others. Therefore this current value was applied in the following experiments. The currents greater than −2 mA was not tend to be applied since the considerably bubbled hydrogen may block the electrode surface. Fig. 11 illustrates a sample CV in alkaline EtOH solution on the electrode modified with −2 mA deposition current. 3.4.2 Deposition current time The applied constant current duration is another essential parameter to be considered for the EOR performance. The bi-metallic electrodeposition on PANI/GCE was done at −2 mA in varied time durations (2, 5, 10 and 15 min). Solutions used in electrodeposition was described in previous section. Table 3 represents the key parameters of EOR in these experiments. It is shown that the difference in each parameter values is negligible after 5 min. Therefore, 5 min is recognized as the optimal constant current duration time to apply for the following experiments. 3.4.3 The effect of Pd:Ag mole ratio Metal ion mole ratio in electrochemical cell solution plays a vital role on the catalytic performance. In this study the electrodeposition solutions with different Pd:Ag mole ratios (1:1, 1:2, 1:4, 2:1 and 4:1) were prepared to examine their effects on the performance of AgPd/PANI composite for EOR (Table 4 ). As can be seen in this table the best result obtained at 1:1 mol ratio. Similar ratio has been used in the previous studies [24,36]. 3.4.4 PANI deposition thickness effect In this study, the effect of cycle number for PANI deposition on the AgPd/PANI/GCE EOR performance was investigated. Four PANI/GCE electrodes were prepared by applying 5, 10, 15 and 20 CVs scan cycles in electropolymerization step and were used to test the EOR performance. The results shown in Table 5 demonstrated that 10 CVs has the best EOR performance and further increase of cycle number causes the drop of peak currents. It may be because of the increase of PANI thickness, leading to the decrease the electrical conductance and decrease of surface roughness. It is also found that a thick PANI film causes the Pd particles embedding into the PANI network, which prohibit the sufficient contact between the active sites with reactants; therefore directing to the peak currents decrease [23]. 3.4.5 The effect of Ag and PANI on EOR A comparison experiments for the EOR efficiency of AgPd/PANI/GCE, Pd/GCE and AgPd/GCE at the optimum deposition conditions were conducted as shown in Fig. 12 . For better comparison, instead of the current (mA), the current density over Pd loaded amount (mA mgPd−1 cm−2) on the electrode surface was plotted vs. E. Fig. 12 shows the CVs which obtained in 1 M EtOH + 0.5 M NaOH. The results show that the co-presence of Ag with Pd increases the EOR current density as well as the onset potential. For the bi-metallic Ag and Pd deposited with PANI on GCE, the onset potential shifts to negative values with an improved EOR current density and i f/i b value, which together results in the enhancement of the EOR efficiency. Followed by above discussions, PANI increases the active surface area and decreases the poisoning of the catalyst by the EOR products. 3.4.6 EOR on AgPd/PANI/CC To expand the application of the obtained bimetallic AgPd composite in fuel cells, the composite was deposited on CC at the developed optimum conditions with a minor modification, which used a wider potential range (−0.4 to 1.2 V) in PANI deposition step. The reason of this method modification is because of that the oxidation peak on CC in the first CV of polymerization step appears near to 1.2 V and the reduction peaks related to three steps of polymerization reaction shift to negative potentials (Fig. 13 ). Since the substrate changed to CC, it is expected to observe the influence on the PANI electropolymerization according to previous reports [34]. Then at the optimum concentrations (1 mM PdCl2 + 1 mM AgNO3 in 0.5 M ammonia buffer) and current density for GCE, Ag-Pd bimetallic was deposited on PANI/CC, as well as the separately deposition of Ag and Pd on PANI/CC. Fig. 14 compares the CV of Ag/PANI/CC, Pd/PANI/CC and AgPd/PANI/CC in 0.5 M H2SO4. The peak around 1 V for Ag/PANI/CC is related to silver oxidation (Fig. 14A) whereas the first redox on the low potentials is related to the hydrogen adsorption/desorption of Pd (Fig. 14B) [23,26]. For AgPd/PANI/CC, the two redox peaks related to Pd and Ag confirms the deposition of Ag-Pd bimetallic structure. The hydrogen adsorption/desorption of Pd is more intensive, which may be related to more accessibility of Pd nanoparticles on the electrode surface. Three other electrodes i.e. Pd/CC, Pd/PANI/CC and AgPd/CC were prepared after the EOR test to compare with the proposed electrode (Fig. 15 ). The results showed that the lowest onset potential and the highest peak current is corresponded to proposed composite modified electrode (AgPd/PANI/CC), which varifies the synergetic effect of Ag and PANI with Pd particles. Therefore, according to simplicity, easy and fast preparation of the proposed electrode can offer an idea method for the preparation of promising electrode for EOR in ethanol fuel cell. 3.4.7 Electrode stability The electrode stability was examined by chronoamperometry technique. In this study two step potentials (−1 and −0.2 V) were applied on the AgPd/PANI/CC and AgPd/CC in 1 M EtOH solution (Fig. 16 ). The results show that these electrodes are almost stable after repeating the potential steps whereas the proposed electrode (AgPd/PANI/CC) performs the better current density related to its competitor electrode (AgPd/CC). By chronoamperometry at longer times (data not shown) and using the following equation [36] the poisoning rate (δ) was calculated: δ = 100 I 0 ( d I d t ) t > 500 s where from the intercept of the regression line with the y-axis, I0 (A) is determined and (dI/dt)t >500 is the slope of the linear part of the curve (A s−1). The poisoning rates at −0.2 V for AgPd/CC and AgPd/PANI/CC were 0.069% and 0.058% s−1, respectively, which means the poisoning in the presence of PANI is lower. 3.4.8 EIS study To investigate the charge transfer resistance (R ct) of EOR, the electrochemical impedance of AgPd/PANI/CC and AgPd/CC were obtained in 0.5 M NaOH containing 1 M EtOH at DC potential of −0.2 V with the amplitude of 0.01 V. The frequency scan was applied between 10−1 to 105 Hz. Fig. 17 shows the Bode plots of this test and the related equivalent circuit is illustrated. According to these plots, there are two waves which reveal that the EOR appears with two electrochemical pathways. One of them has the lower height which is performed on the alloy catalyst layer and the other one has the greater wave height which is performed without alloy catalyst layer. As the figure shows for both pathways, R ct for AgPd/PANI/CC is lower than AgPd/CC. This observation further confirms the better performance of our proposed electrode related to AgPd/CC for EOR. 4 Conclusion In this work, for the first time, Ag and Pd were electrochemically deposited on PANI coated GCE, and this modified electrode was used for EOR. Some important parameters including constant current density for Ag-Pd bimetallic deposition, deposition time, Pd:Ag mole ratio in deposition solution and PANI layer thickness were optimized on GCE. To produce a more applicable electrode for EOR, at the optimized condition, the same composite layer was deposited on CC. To compare the proposed electrode performance for EOR, some other modified electrodes (with Ag or Ag/PANI, Pd or Pd/PANI) were prepared. To study the physiochemical properties of the prepared electrodes, SEM, XRD and ICP were characterized and the EOR was tested on the proposed electrodes to evaluate the catalytic performance. The results showed that the best EOR performance is corresponded to AgPd/PANI layer on CC or GCE. According to low cost, easy and fast preparation, the proposed electrode can be promising anode electrode in alcohol fuel cells and expected to expand the application to ethanol sensors as well. coredata.dc:description: In recent years bi-metallic materials have shown promising effect as potential catalyst layer in the fuel cells. Here, for the first time, bimetallic Ag-Pd were electrodeposited on polyaniline/glassy carbon electrode (PANI/GCE) via the constant current method, which used as efficient electrode for ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR) in alkaline media. Some important parameters including applied current, deposition time and metal ratio were optimized. The obtained bimetallic AgPd/PANI/GCE catalyst showed improved catalytic performance for ethanol conversion compared with the Pd/PANI/GCE, Pd/GCE, Ag/PANI/GCE, and PANI/GCE. The catalytic enhancement is due to the synergic effect between Ag, Pd and PANI. Moreover, the proposed AgPd composite was deposited on the carbon fiber cloth (CC) to evaluate its applicability as an anode in ethanol fuel cell. To summarize, the good electrochemical performance and easy preparation make the obtained Ag-Pd bimetallic composite as a potential candidate for alkaline ethanol fuel cell.
coredata.dc:title: Palladium-silver polyaniline composite as an efficient catalyst for ethanol oxidation
